answers.answer: Dear Buttercup109,CME or cystoids macular edema is swelling in the area of one’s central vision. I would recommend that you seek the care of an eyeMD specializing in retina.  Sometimes, one can develop inflammation after cataract surgery that can contribute to the macular edema.  Cystoid macular edema also occurs in individuals with diabetes, uveitis [inflammation inside the eye] or after retinal vein occlusions.  It is not likely that computer use is the cause of your chronic condition.  The treatment of CME can include topical steroid and non-steroidal anti-inflammatories, oral or injected anti-inflammatories, and diuretics such as diamox.  If the cause can be elucidated, then further treatment can be aimed at that.  Should the CME not improve despite all of these, the vitrectomy and the vision loss substantial, an IOL exchange can be performed.  Sometimes, it can take a long time for the edema to improve after addressing the cause.Dr. FeldmanSandy T. Feldman, M.D., M.S.ClearView Eye and Laser Medical CenterSan Diego, California
